I dispatched that moment an express to where our regi∣ment lay in quarters; and ingenuously confessing my misconduct, begged a brother officer to lend me what I wanted.

How! replied that officer, give up so great a sum of money to a professed gambler? No; if I must either lose
my property, or give up my connection with a man whose conduct makes his friendship infamous, I chuse to keep my property.

Immediately on reading this insulting answer, I was utterly beside myself; and still remember, as what hap∣pened yesterday, the dreadful images which all at once came crowding into my imagination: on the one hand, the distress and indignation of my father, the dishonour that I was fixing on my family, as well as on every one that knew me, and the dread of being broke with in∣famy; on the other hand, the briliant prospect of that promotion which I might have obtained, by an honour∣able conduct in my post: nor did I afterwards recover the possession of my understanding, but to think of perpetra∣ting a new crime, that I might be delivered from that ignominy which my first would bring upon me. I was ready to go through with such a desperate resolution, when I saw the very officer come into my apartment, whose reply had hurried me, as I have said just now, into this state of madness.

In the first emotion of my rage, I fell upon him like a fiend; but he disarmed me very quickly; and while I but little thought of what was to ensue, embraced me, and began as follows. "I replied a little harshly to your letter, as I meant, by such an answer, that you should see the horror of that situation into which your rashness has pecipitated you; and I perceive what effect it has up∣on you. Now therefore that you repent, my property, my life, and every thing that I have, you may command, as you think proper."
"Here," continued he, and threw his purse upon the table, "here is what will serve to pay your new recruits: and the remainder may supply you at the gaming-table, if you mean to return thither."
Return to the gaming-table! Never, never, answered I; and clasped him to my heart.

Since which, I have precisely kept my word. From that day forward I determined to have done with all expen∣sive pleasures, and apply my savings to the purpose of re∣paying what my generous friend had lent me. I employed my leisure time in study. My attention to the service recommended me to my superiors; and to such a happy
lution in the course of my affairs I am indebted for the honour of my present station in the army.

This recital made so powerful an impression on his officers, that every game of hazard ceased among them, and a noble emulation to arrive at useful knowledge quenched that low ambition of winning money which was their ruling passion before. Such was the good conse∣quence resulting from their prudent colonel's lesson.

DIV2.HEAD: THE PRODIGAL DOUBLY PUNISHED.
DIV2.P: A Worthy private gentleman, observing with concern his only son upon the point of taking to a spend∣thrift way of living, let him do as he thought proper; and it was not long before the son had run himself behind hand to a great amount. I will pay whatever debt you may contract, said the father to him, as my honour is much dearer to me than my money; but take notice of what follows: You love joyous living, and I love the poor. I have given away in charity a great deal less than I was used to do before I thought of your establishment. I will think no longer of it; a libertine should never marry; so indulge yourself as much as you think proper, but on this condition: I declare, that when, at any time, you spend beyond the money which I allow you to keep yourself as a gentleman, some hospital, or other charitable institution, shall receive from me as much as you require to satisfy your debts; and I will begin this very day. Accordingly the money was that moment ordered to a certain charity; and thus the youth, on being doubly punished for his pro∣digality, was quickly cured of a disease which otherwise would have insured his ruin.

DIV3.HEAD: CHARACTERS.
DIV3.P: The SCENE is in the garden of Mr. Fletcher; during the first act, in one part, after which it changes to another part.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: WHAT have you to do at Augustine's, then?

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: I want to have a little conversation with him, Albert; and you know him likewise.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: Yes, by sight. You have not always been so intimate, I fancy, as you are at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: Not before my father took a lodging here, adjoining his apartments. We see one another often now; and last night were together for an hour or two, at cards.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: I think, of late, you talk of nothing else but cards; and I have seen you frequently along with Rich and Vyse, of whom I cannot say any good.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: You know them but too well; and would to heaven that I had never seen them!

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: Is it so? But you may break off their acquaint∣ance when you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: That is not, at present, in my power. Would you betray me, if I told you something?

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: We have long been friends; and would you fear to trust me, Jonathan?

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: O my dear good Albert! they have made me miserable, and engaged me to do things for which my fa∣ther would renounce me if he knew them. I have not a moment's peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: Alas! what are they?

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: Yesterday they got me to go with them to a place where one Crib waited for them. We sat down to play, and I lost all I had.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: They cheated you, no doubt. But still there is no great mischief done; for never play again, and then your loss will be a gain.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: But this is not the whole. As I had no more money, and still wanted to win back my loss, I still played on, and in the end they got possession of my watch, my coat and waistcoat buttons, buckles, and, in short, of every thing that I had worth selling. I owe Crib a guinea likewise, and he will tell my father, if I cannot find means to pay him to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: There is but one thing that you can do. Con∣fess the whole directly to your father. I am sure, he will pardon you on your repentance.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: Never! never!

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: What will you do, then?

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: I dare not tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: Let me know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: I communicated my distress to Rich and Vyse, and they advised a scheme to extricate me.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: A fine scheme, no doubt!

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: It is not certainly the fairest, as you will say; but what am I at liberty to do▪ I have already introduced them to young Augustine. He has money.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: Well: you do not intend to rob him, surely?

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: Heaven forbid! They only mean to serve him just as Crib served me; and then we are to share the winnings, so that I may pay my debt.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: And so, because you have been pillaged your∣self, you would assist them to defraud your friend too? But how know you that Augustine will not win?

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: Oh! no: he plays quite fair.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: And you like a sharper?

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: Like a sharper?

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: No; I am sensible that you play as fair as Au∣gustine, and therefore you lost. Now, as I hope you al∣ways mean to play so, how can you be sure of winning?

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: I do not know how it is; but they inform me that they have certain ways by which they are sure of winning.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: Ways! They are knavish tricks, and would you use them? I am not rich, and yet I would not mend my fortune by your certain ways. I am even sorry that you have told me your intention.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: My dear Albert, have compassion on me, and I promise—

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: Promise! What can bring me to assist in your deception?

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: No; I mean to say, that if I am but so lucky as to pay this odious Crib, I will break off all connexion with him and his friends; and never touch a card again. If I should break this promise, you shall be at liberty to tell my father every thing. (Albert shakes his head.) Yes, every thing. And then, it will not rest with me to cheat: I cannot if I would, and Crib has taken that upon him∣self. I shall but play my cards: they have promised that I shall be no loser, but divide the profit with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: Well; I will make a party with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: I desire no better, and will instantly invite young Augustine for the afternoon. His father is at pre∣sent in the country, and will not come back perhaps these three weeks.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: Quite convenient! But take notice, if your∣self should cheat him—

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: Do not talk so. I wish I had not told you∣the affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: And so do I. I should not then be answerable for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: Answerable?

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: To my conscience, surely. I can see a worthy youth on the point of being cheated.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: But you will not cheat him.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: Jonathan, if you saw a thief pick even a stran∣ger's pocket, ought you to keep silence?

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: Augustine will but lose two, three, or pos∣sibly four guineas, and be cured of playing.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: Just as you are cured. But here comes Augus∣tine, I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Good morrow to you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: Good morrow, Augustine.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: What, you have not been down yet into the garden, when it is such fine weather?

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: Mr. Augustine does not like to run about as you do, and can entertain himself in his apartment.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Yes; but I have been already walking in the garden, and even breakfasted with Honoria and my father in the grove.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: (surprized.) Is he returned so soon? I fancy, you are not well pleased at that.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Not well pleased! when he has been three weeks away?

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: I love my parents well enough; and yet, if they should take it in their heads to travel, it would not vex me.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: And, for my part, I could wish my father never out of fight, he is so extremely kind!

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: And mine so harsh, I must not think of plea∣sure when he is near me.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: Who can tell what pleasures you expect!

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: I thought you were in want of nothing on that head. Since we have lodged together, I have almost every day observed you at the door; and when I have met you in the garden, never could I see you under any thing appearing like restraint.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: No, no; I have always met you on days when my father dined abroad, and that is the only time that I have to use as I think proper; therefore I do turn it to account. But now your father is come home, I take it, we shall not see you quite so often in an evening?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Why not, Jonathan? He refuses me no pleasure that I can ask. However, I must say, I find no company like his; and he, too, has frequently said that he thinks my company and Honoria's quite delightful.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: What a charming father! So then he per∣mits you to go out both when and where you like?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: He does, because I always tell him where I am going.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: And because he knows that you never go but where you tell him?

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: What then do you do for entertainment, when you are both together?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: In the summer evenings, frequently we take a walk.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: In winter?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: We sit down before the fire, and talk of fifty curious matters; or I study geography, and take a lesson in the mathematics. Sometimes too, with Honoria and a friend or two, we act a little drama of some kind or other. You cannot think how that amuses us!

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: But sure such different studies are enough to crack your brain!

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: On the contrary, they come of course, as if they were an amusement.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: A game at cards I should suppose much more amusing. Do you ever play?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Yes, truly; and my father frequently makes one.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: And do you play for money?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Doubtless; but a trifle, just enough to in∣terest one in the game; and particularly, as by that, my father says, one learns to lose with temper.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: That is quite right; one ought to husband, as they say, one's purse,

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Oh! do not imagine that I want money. I have more than I can use.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: How much?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: A crown a week.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: A good allowance, truly! And all that to purchase trifles?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Yes, such trifles as my father would not like to have me trouble him about; and that, I must acknow∣ledge, makes me much more careful.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: I believe so. One can hardly chuse but know the worth of things, when one must pay for them one's self.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P:
True, Albert. And besides, one naturally saves in that case, as I myself have found it; so that what
with presents and some other matters, I have now five guineas in my pocket, without reckoning silver.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: Such a deal! And how can you employ it?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Have I nothing then to buy? However, I can dispose of it otherwise. I pay to have our footman's daughter put to school; and every Monday morning send a trifle to a writing-master that I had once, and who is now grown blind: these, both together, make up some∣thing; and I keep the rest for ordinary uses, and among them, for play.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: At which you are tolerably lucky. You re∣member, you won half a crown of me the other night, at One-and-thirty.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: I was sorry, as I always am, to win of friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: Then you shall have an opportunity at night of losing, if you think fit. Are you engaged?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: No; I shall stay at home. My father is to draw out a petition for a widow woman, who would get into an alms-house.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: That is well: and mine goes out at five. Come then to me, and I will endeavour to amuse you. We shall have Rich, Vyse, and Crib.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: I will run and ask my father's leave. Shall you be here when I return?

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: No, I must go and give them notice of the party; but your answer Mr. Albert will bring to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Will you go in with me, Mr. Albert? I am sure, my father will be very glad to see you: he has often told me what a great esteem he has conceived this long while for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: I am very happy in his partiality. The esteem of such a gentleman is highly honourable; but at present I am rather indisposed, and shall remain, with your per∣mission, in the garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Do; a turn or two will settle you, and I shall not be absent long.

I do not know what to do in this affair! Poor Jonathan is afflicted! I should like to extricate him; but then to let the worthy Augustine be cheated! No, the accomplice is not better than the robber; and to favour roguery is just as bad as doing it. I will go therefore and tell the whole. But, softly! here comes Honoria. Let me first of all do every thing in my power to assist her in pre∣serving Augustine from the danger, and yet not betray my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: What, you here, Mr. Albert, and alone? I thought I saw my brother talking with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: He has just now left me.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: I should wish him never to leave you, if his company were but agreeable to you: I should not be uneasy then.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: You do me honour, miss; but surely Mr. Augustine is too sensible to give you any pain.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: I have no pain while he keeps company with such as you: but shall I come directly to the point? I do not think any good of those companions of Jonathan's; and he wants by all means to mix with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: I have not yet perceived that their company has hurt him.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: True; but my poor brother, I must say, is innocent, and somewhat credulous: he judges every one to be like himself. What would become of him, if those whom he thinks his friends were what they should not be? I have remarked, that you do not much approve of Jona∣than's intimates.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: To say the truth, my dear young lady, I should rather wish that Jonathan would be satisfied with Augus∣tine's friendship. There is one advantage, notwithstand∣ing, that his father watches over him, as yours does over Augustine, and instructs him what to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: The mischief often is remarked too late; it is easier to prevent than cure it.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: I am sure, you love your brother tenderly, and therefore hear me; but tell nobody that I mentioned what I am going now to say. Young Jonathan has pre∣vailed upon him, just before you entered, to make one with him and his three intimates. They mean to play, no doubt; but do your utmost to divert your brother from partaking with them. I designed to wait here for his an∣swer, but do not think it proper that I should carry it. I make no doubt but he will bring it presently. Pray do not judge amiss of me that I retire; and think of the ad∣vice which my duty, as a friend to Augustine, bade me give you.

As a friend! This looks a little serious! Ah, my poor dear brother! should it chance that you, who are at pre∣sent all the joy and consolation of my father, were to change, and be the cause of his affliction for the time to come!

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: My father's friends are willing, I can see, to take the earliest opportunity of paying him their com∣pliments on his arrival, just as if he had been absent for a twelvemonth. I could hardly thrust a word in.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: You had something then of consequence to tell him.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Of the greatest consequence to me. I want to pass the evening with my friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: With Mr. Jonathan, no doubt?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: I thought so. You might easily have guessed, however, that such a friend as Jonathan does not please me.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P:
Truly, Jonathan is greatly to be pitied, being so unfortunate as not to have a place in your
good graces! And what should he be, to merit such an honour?

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: He should be—just such a one as you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Do you mean to joke?

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: No: I am very serious, I assure you; and consider you a very amiable young man without a fault, unless indeed it be the want of due politeness to your sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: And why so? because that sister is a little critic, and pretends to greater understanding than her brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: Truly, I had quite forgot to mention modesty, when I was drawing up your panegyric.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: But what means this prating? and pray tell me, why these intimations with regard to Jonathan! Do you know him?

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: I would know him by his actions.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Are you always with him, to remark them?

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: I can guess them from the company that he keeps.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: I understand you perfectly: his company dis∣pleases you, because I am one of his acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: Surely, brother, he must have acquaintances of longer standing than yourself; and I speak of them as I would of good for nothing fellows.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Good for nothing fellows?

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: Yes, that play, and practise each dishonour∣able trick to win their adversary's money, and then spend it more dishonourably still.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Oh! what two great crimes! they play when they are together; and they spend their winnings as they please. We do the same, I fancy. And besides, you say, they play to win; but they have often lost to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: Yes, yes; they have lost their copper, and have won your silver.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Well, and if they have, the loss was mine, not yours. But this is just like what my sister is. She would be sorry if she could not vex me in my pleasures, notwithstanding I do every thing to heighten hers.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria,
SP.P:
(taking him by the hand.) No, brother; every pleasure that you can have, is also mine; but for the world, I would not have your pleasures hurt you, and
deprive me of the satisfaction which I receive from loving you.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: I know indeed that you love me; but am hurt to find you fancy me incapable to guide myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: And yet you would not be the first that—but here comes my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: My dear children, I have just now been enjoying a delightful satisfaction!

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: That of being visited on your return by your acquaintance, I suppose you mean? But certainly your friends must cherish you, when we who are restrained by your authority, rejoice as much as they can do.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Yes, truly; for without you we can find no pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: And yet you must learn to do without me; since, according to the ordinary course of nature, I shall certainly go first.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: O sir, would you afflict us at a time when we thought of nothing but rejoicing?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Yes, sir, you will live, and long we hope, for our advantage. But let us talk no more on such a gloomy subject.—I have a little favour to request.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: Well, come, let us hear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Master Jonathan—you are acquainted with his father—Well, he has invited me to spend the evening with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: You have a new acquaintance then. I am glad that you pick up such good company so near you.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: You hear that? good company!

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: I think him so; I have already sat down with him several times, and he has introduced me also to some friends of his.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: Good company, too, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Yes, for sure I must know them better than you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: When I used the words good company, I meant discreet and well bred.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Yes, sir, extremely so.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: And how are you to know that they are such, as you have only seen them once or twice?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: But have I not been hours together with them?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: How did your acquaintance begin?

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: At play.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: And why not so? My father lets me play.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: It is true, for recreation, and for such a sum as being gained will not induce the immoderate love of money, or if lost, not put one out of temper; and this likewise at a time when nothing can be done more pro∣fitable.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: But I thought, sir, something might be always done more profitable?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Yes, (I speak of myself, for instance,) if I could but nail my thoughts continually to some book or other.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: Honoria's remark is not amiss. One may employ a leisure evening better than at play, no doubt, if people would be always rational, or even inno∣cently mirthful; but as scandal sometimes will go round, or folly; in such case, you know, I bid you play, and often take a part myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: And these I doubt not, brother, are the reasons why you play?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: I do not see any right that you have to cate∣chize me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: But why take offence at what she says through friendship?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Rather, sir, from a desire to hurt me in your thoughts.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: Can you conceive such notions of your sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria,
SP.P: (with a tone of tenderness.) Brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine,
SP.P: (with the same tone.) Honoria, pardon me: I am in the wrong to tax you thus: but grant, however, your insinuations unavoidably must hurt me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: Her suspicions may have some foundation that does not reflect upon you: we need not fear, I think, our dispositions towards each other, so united as we are. (Honoria and Augustine take their father by the hand.)

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: O sir, how good you are!

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: You lay by all a father's rights, and are our friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: If I were any other than your friend, I should not be compleatly qualified to bring you up. I might perhaps connive at your neglecting outward cere∣monies of respect; but not your failure in that confidence which I expect from your affection. You should not have a secret that you would keep hid from me, as whenever you may chance to be in danger, my experience may pre∣serve you from it. Let me therefore ask you, Honoria, what are the objections that you have formed against your brother's new acquaintances?

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: They are always taken up with cards.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Who told you so?

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: No matter from whom I have my information: the thing is, whether it be true?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: I have already told you what I think of playing: every thing depends upon the game that you play.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Oh! it needs no great attention: it is the game of one and thirty.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: I confess, I do not approve it much.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Why not? There can be nothing in the world so innocent. Whoever is one and thirty, or the nearest to it, wins.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: And do you know that it is what we call a game of chance?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Because one has a chance to win or lose? and must not this be said of every game?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: With this material difference, that at one and thirty, chance alone decides; whereas, in many others, skill is to be shown. In short, one wants but fingers, and no head for games of chance: and in my thought, such games are utterly unworthy of a thinking man.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: They cannot even amuse one.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Do not say so, dear sister. There is a deal of pleasure in expecting such or such a card as one may want.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: Because the love of money makes it so. And as this love of money operates very powerfully, it is a strong temptation for ten thousand rogues to follow gaming as a trade; and therefore unsuspecting people ge∣nerally are their dupes.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Do you believe so, sir? but how?

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: I fancy, they must have some art or other, to arrange the pack in such a way, as to obtain what cards they want.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: Yes, that is in reality their secret. I can∣not tell their method; but am certain, that they do em∣ploy some method, and have seen deplorable examples of it in my travels.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Oh! pray tell us what examples?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: With a deal of pleasure. When at Spa, I was acquainted with a young gentleman, who lost one night above twelve thousand pounds, which was his all.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: His all! poor youth! and what did he do to live?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: He must have been beside himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: Despair obtained possession of his features, when he saw his fortune thus irretrievably lost. He looked so frightful, that I was forced to turn away my sight; he gnashed his teeth, plucked up his hair by handfuls, and beat violently on his breast: he gasped and panted like a dying man, and left the room quite mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: And pray, sir, among those who won his money, was there no one who would give it back, as I should certainly have done?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: They kept their seats; and still continued playing on: or if they turned off their attention from the cards, it was to look upon him with contempt.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: The wicked wretches!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: But the worst part of the story is as fol∣lows: That this poor young man destroyed himself before the morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: Oh! how shocking!

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Dreadful! and from henceforth, sir, I will never touch a card, I promise you. I'll run and tell this Jonathan.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: Softly, softly: you are always much too hasty in your resolutions. One should never wholly give a pleasure up, because, when carried to excess, it may be hurtful. I have often told you, that a game at cards, when friends are met together, is amusing, innocent, and even useful.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: Useful, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: Yes, useful; as it teaches us to bear our fortune; and not to triumph when we win, or be dejected at our little losses.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Heaven be praised, I am not so fond of money as to hurt another by my insults in good fortune; or to shew that I am hurt myself, by being vexed when I am un∣lucky; but to shun what possibly might happen, it will be better for me not to visit either Jonathan or his friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: You would only prove your weakness, if this should be your final resolution: for at least you have it in your power, when with them, to refrain from playing.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Oh, I know them: they would absolutely make me play.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: Well, play as much as they would have you, since by that means you will gain a better knowledge of them. But instead of going to this Jonathan, or his friends, invite them hither. You may also tell them that Honoria perhaps will make one.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: But, sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: Yes, yes; I have a reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: But suppose they win my money?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: You shall have it all from me again. And tell them, Augustine, that you expect a friend, whom you will prevail on to sit down and play amongst them.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: But you know, sir, I expect no friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: When I inform you of a friend that you have at home, who will be with you, cannot you guess what friend I mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: Sly! Why sure you understand papa? he means himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: Yes, Augustine; for you recollect, just now you said that I was your friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Oh yes; they will play indeed, if you are of the party!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: Therefore you shall not inform them who the friend is that you expect. As soon as I have finished my petition, I will return and join you. I shall see what is proper to be done. 'Till then, play with them, and at any game they chuse.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: So then you would have me run to Jonathan and his friends?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: Yes, yes: and do not forget to desire Al∣bert's company. I shall be glad to see him. All his masters praise him wonderfully, and you yourself have fre∣quently been lavish in his commendations.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: He merits every tittle of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: One word more, sir; shall we meet here in the garden?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: As your please. The weather is so fine, you may step here into the summer-house, it will hold all your company.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: I fear, sir, your presence will be much more necessary here than mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: You fear?

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: Yes, sir; for I have told you, Master Albert was not long since with me. From some words which he dropped, I have reason to believe that my brother's com∣pany have laid a plot to cheat him of his money.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: All the better, if he finds himself their victim. I will hide myself behind the summer-house there, just by that partition, and hear every word of their discourse. They will enter here, and cannot possibly dis∣cover me: but in the interim take you care; and if you see their roguery, seem as if you did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: I shall find it hard, sir, to dissemble. It will be painful to me, should I see my brother prove the object of their ridicule, and fall a victim to his open nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: By himself alone can he be fully unde∣ceived; and in that case I shall with less difficulty per∣suade him to be attentive for the future in the choice of his connexions, and so cure him likewise of his love for gaming, which, I must acknowledge, he seems ready to adopt as a habit.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: How, sir, can he have a thought of going thus to cards? He ought to know himself. He is so cre∣dulous, that every sharper must suppose him proper for his purpose! and so warm, that at the first ill luck he falls into a passion!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: Yes, that is just his character. I did not think you so observant, Honoria.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: One should be in truth observant of another's conduct, if one means to serve him. And—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: A knock; it must be Jonathan's friends: they do not desire to lose a moment. I now leave you. I will go round about and gain my station. (He goes out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria,
SP.P: (alone.) How I long to know the issue of all this! Alas! dear brother! who can tell but your future happiness in life depends on the decision of the present afternoon.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XI.
DIV3.STAGE: Honoria, Augustine, Jonathan, Albert, Rich, Vyse, Crib.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan,
SP.P: (to Honoria.) I was afraid, Miss Honoria, as I mentioned to your brother, that our company might in∣commode you: but he would not—

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Incommode her! I am in hopes that she will keep us company.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: With all my heart, if you think proper, gen∣tlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Vyse,
SP.P: (with constraint.) You do us honour, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Crib,
SP.P: (whispering Jonathan.) This is quite unlucky! In politeness we must play whatever game she likes. You should not have consented to come here.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Perhaps I shall be able, gentlemen, to intro∣duce a friend of mine to your acquaintance likewise.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: Shall you?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Yes, and not without a pocket full of gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan,
SP.P: (aside.) That is well.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: We will stay here in the garden, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: We cannot do better. We shall have the plea∣sure of a charming walk.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: Do you design to walk?

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: What else?

SP.SPEAKER: Vyse.
SP.P: Why, play.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: But I do not understand your play; and if I did, I shall not wish to lose my money.

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: Wish to lose it! just as if it were certain that you would lose it!

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: Sir, with you particularly. You are too skilful by a deal for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: If I should win, I promise, I will return you every farthing.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: And I too.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich and Vyse.
SP.P: And we.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: You would make a fool of me. To lose my money, and receive it back, or on the other hand, win yours, and keep it, is not what I do: so do not concern yourselves on my account. I will see you play, or else walk up and down the garden hereabouts.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: My father, gentlemen, cannot have the ho∣nour to receive you, (Rich and his company seem rejoiced,) but has bid me entertain you. Augustine will get ready some refreshments, and I will run and fetch the cards.

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: That is needless: I have a pack about me.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: How! about you?

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: Yes: I study them.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: And have you fish too?

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: I shall beg you to get us them, unless we are to stake our money.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan,
SP.P: (aside to Crib.) You remember, I have no money?— (aloud.) No, no: we shall hardly know what we are about. And so, miss, if you will be so kind—

SP.SPEAKER: Monoria.
SP.P: Enough, I will bring the bag. Come, brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Vyse,
SP.P: (going into the summer-house with Jonathan, Rich, and Crib, while Albert walks about.) I am sorry we are here.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: What matters, since the father is not here?

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: You should not have consented to the place of meeting, Jonathan.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: Here, or in my room, what difference does that make?

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: Well then, when Augustine has lost every thing, we will carry off his money, and go play where we think proper.

SP.SPEAKER: Vyse.
SP.P: We shall empty, very likely, the young lady's pocket also.

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: Yes; that is what I look for: let us take care, however. We will put in our fish at two-pence each, for half a dozen deals or so; and when the game grows warm, and they have won a little, we will then make them double.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: You remember your promise, Crib?

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: Do not you be uneasy. We know one another. All our loss shall be in counters, and we will have no reckoning when the game is over. I will dispose the cards in such a way, that we must lose at first, and that will draw them on.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: But, Crib, you know, you fleeced me quite the other day; and I have now but sixpence in my pocket. How am I to pay my loss?

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: Your loss! we shall be sure to win, if we attend to what we do.

SP.SPEAKER: Vyse.
SP.P: I should be glad if Augustine's friend would come: he will be another pigeon that we shall pluck.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: Yes, yes! I know of none so easy to be duped as these same bookish fellows.

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: We had best begin, that they may find us busy when they come. (He takes his cards out.) Stay; I will put them so that you may lose. (He shuffles them.) Now you shall see. (He gives three cards to Jonathan, Rich, and Vyse; lays down as many for himself, and then addresses Jo∣nathan.) Do you stand?

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: No: beg.

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: There.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan,
SP.P: (looking at the cards.) Out!

SP.SPEAKER: Crib,
SP.P: (to Vyse.) And you?

SP.SPEAKER: Vyse.
SP.P: One card, but not a high one.

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: Much good may it do you!—there.

SP.SPEAKER: Vyse.
SP.P: Out too!

SP.SPEAKER: Crib,
SP.P: (to Rich.) Now you are to be out. You beg, I suppose?

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: No; as Vyse and Jonathan are both out, I stand.

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: And so will I. How many are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Vyse.
SP.P: Twenty-five.

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P:
And I just thirty. I have won: And yet I might have lost by doing the reverse of what I did; as you shall see the two first games that we play, when Augustine and
the lady comes, who having won, will then have no ob∣jection to play higher.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: But how can you be sure of winning when you please?

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: You have already paid for your instruction, and I will let you know the secret. I tell every thing to friends, when I have pocketed their money. With my art you will win of others what you have lost of me, and so be quits.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: Well, let me know.

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: You see, (shewing the cards,) the ten and court cards are a very little longer than the rest, and all the smaller ones, as high as five, not reckoning in the aces, somewhat broader; by which means I can at pleasure bring the picture cards, &c. to the top in shuffling, and the five, and those below it, to the bottom. I contrive to give you two of those on the top; and afterward, the other from the bottom: so that at the most you have but five and twenty, and will therefore generally beg. Well then, you have it from the top, and must infallibly be out.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: I understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: This is all my lesson, and you have it upon easy terms; ask Rich and Vyse else, who so profitably follow my instructions. But I see the lady coming in, so push about the deal.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria,
SP.P: (putting down a box upon the table, with a pack of cards and fish and counters in it.) You do not lose any time, I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: I was but showing Mr. Jonathan a new game.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: You will sit down with us? We shall have that honour?

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: If I knew the game that you play—

SP.SPEAKER: Vyse.
SP.P: It is a very easy game. It is only One and thirty.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: Had you never seen it played, you will know enough to beat us at it by the second deal.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P:
I know a little of it. It would perhaps be better for me not to play with those that know it so com∣pletely
as you gentlemen; however, if it gives you plea∣sure—

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: Oh yes, miss, the greatest in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Vyse.
SP.P: And even should you win, too, all our money.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria,
SP.P: (with a smile.) Yes, that is my intention.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: You will be scarce the richer for it in the end; we play but for a trifle.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan,
SP.P: (with impatience.) Well! and what are we about? We pass away the time in talking.

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: We must wait for Master Augustine: it is but just that we should amuse him; we are his guests.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XIV.
DIV3.STAGE: Jonathan, Rich, Vyse, Crib, Honoria, Augustine.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Here, here I am. The servant will be with us very shortly. I have ordered some refreshment.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: Come, sir, we are waiting for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: Vyse.
SP.P: Let us give out the fish.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: There are six of us: to every one two dozen, and ten counters; that is, ten dozen more.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: But how much every fish?

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: Just what the lady pleases.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: Oh, it is rather as you like.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Our fish were two-pence each, when last we played together; five staked every deal by each, and half a dozen the bon-ace.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: Well, be it so.

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: Then here goes to begin. (Crib takes the cards and deals. The lady and her brother win by (rib's contriv∣ance three times running.)

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: Hey! hey! if we go on in this way, I think, I shall soon fulfil my prophecy.

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: While we play so low as two-pence, we shall never ruin one another.

SP.SPEAKER: Vyse.
SP.P: Well then, shall we make it four-pence?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Oh, with all my heart. I have so much money, you cannot break me easily. (He shakes his purse, at which Crib and his companions look with pleasure.)

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: And I can risque as much, I fancy, as my brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: We must first then pay our debts, that we may have our full account of fish and counters.—Let me see, (after having counted.) I have lost one counter, and six fish; that is, eighteen fish; and eighteen twice is six and thirty —just three shillings: there they are.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: I have all my counters, but am master of no more than two poor fish; that is two and twenty lost, or three and eight-pence. There.

SP.SPEAKER: Vyse.
SP.P: I am come off much the worst. Two counters gone, and twice as many fish; which come to four and eight-pence.—I put down a crown, and take up four∣pence.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Well, and you, Master Jonathan?

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: I have lost least. No more than fifteen fish, or half a-crown. I will change a guinea, when we rise, to pay it.

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: Good! So now I will see my winnings. One, two, three—Three counters, and three fish. That is six and six-pence just: of which I take four shillings, and the two and six-pence, Master Jonathan, you shall owe me.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: So that all the rest is to pay my four and forty fish.—It is comical enough, however, that we should be the only winners!

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: Oh, I always lose, for my part.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: So now the fish are four-pence?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Yes, that is settled.

SP.SPEAKER: Crib.
SP.P: (shuffling the cards.) Come, I will deal.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE THE LAST.
DIV3.STAGE: Jonathan, Rich, Vyse, Crib, Honoria, Augustine, Albert, (who came in a little while before,) Mr. Fletcher.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher,
SP.P: (to Jonathan and his friends, who seem con∣founded.) Pray do not disturb yourselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Sit down: my father does not come to inter∣rupt us, I informed you that I might have a friend to introduce, and he will play with us. Won't you, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: O yes: pray play; we shall be very glad to get your money, and these gentlemen, I know, will like to share it too.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P:
With all my heart. So every one fit down. (To Jonathan and his friends, who seem quite over∣whelmed.)
But what is the matter, gentlemen? Are you afraid to play with me? I can assure you, I am no sharper. (They sit down at last.) You (to Crib) were dealing when I entered; so continue pray; but first let us see, have you a pack complete? (Crib wants to drop the cards, but Mr. Fletcher secures, and looks them over.) It is droll enough to have the court-cards all together thus! but, Honoria, why not give us cleaner cards? Pray hand me over those—

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: It was not my fault, sir, as this gentleman (pointing to Crib) had brought them in his pocket; and the play was going on when I came in with ours.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher,
SP.P: (to Albert.) What, you here, Master Al∣bert! I am very glad to see you; but pray, do not you play?

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: I would rather be a looker on: you know I have nothing, sir, to throw away.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: You are in the right to think so, and your prudence merits praise. (To Crib.) But come, sir; here are better cards, (Crib takes them with a trembling band,) at least a little cleaner: what is your game? Pray tell me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: And for what?

SP.SPEAKER: Honoria.
SP.P: No more than four-pence a fish. I have won all this! four shillings; and two and six-pence owing me by Mr. Jonathan, who wants change.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher,
SP.P: (aside.) Wants change! I smell a rat! (to Honoria.) So much as four-pence! that is a little too much; but no matter, if we have all of us enough to pay our losings. So let us see your money. Mr. Jonathan, I begin with you; (Jonathan is confused.) What ails you? Are you taken ill?

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: Ye-e-es, sir—Let me—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: What is all this? one stammers, and the other seems confounded! (to Crib.) You, sir, too, are dis∣concerted?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: What is the matter with them?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: It is high time that I should explain the reason of this strange behaviour. Augustine, you observe the effects of a guilty conscience. Happily they are not yet so totally abandoned as to hide their villainy beneath a brazen front, and bully in their own defence.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: What say you, sir? Sure you are mistaken: It is my sister, as she told you, and myself, that are the only winners.

SP.SPEAKER: Crib,
SP.P: (taking courage.) Have we failed to pay our losings, every one, but Master Jonathan?

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: No: but why? because you have cheated me already out of all my money.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: I was right in thinking that they would unmask themselves: And, Augustine, you may see what villains you have chosen for your companions.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Oh, I cannot think so, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: Well then, Mr. Jonathan, do you speak; you seem least hardened. Tell me, was there not a plot among you to defraud my children?

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: Yes indeed, sir; but for my part, I assure you, I was forced into it. All my wish was to get back a part of what I had lost before. If you but knew how much this wicked fellow has squeezed from me, for the other two are nothing to him, you would say that he should be sent to prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: You have well deserved your loss, by mix∣ing with such company: but tell me how much you have lost?

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: Two guineas, and a few odd shillings with them all together; and my watch, coat buttons, buckles, and a guinea more in money afterwards, in private with the tallest: but the guinea I still owe him; and he threat∣ened, if I did not prevail on Master Augustine to fit down and play this evening, that he would tell my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: This, sir, I can say in Jonathan's favour, that he gave me just the same account this morning, and was grieved at what he thought himself compelled to do. The grand criminal is Crib, the tallest; the two others in comparison—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: I comprehend what you would say; and therefore, (to Rich and Vyse,) little rascals, get you gone this instant. Perhaps it is not as yet too late that I should think of rescuing you from infamy; and therefore I will inform your parents of your conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich and Vyse,
SP.P: (dropping on their knees.) Pardon us this once, sir, we beseech you; and we will never come within your doors again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: No; I shall take care that you never do; but then it is not enough that my children should be safe in future from your roguery, I owe the same good service to all fathers. What perversity! at such an age not only to be gamblers, but vile cheats! the hatefullest of human beings! However, out of pity to your youth, and from the hope which I have of your amendment, I will do no more than tell your parents; but if ever I am told that you still continue your detestable employment, I will make known your infamy to every one about us. So be gone, and never let me see you here again. Be gone, I say. (Rich and Vyse withdraw in silence and confusion.) And you, sir, is it true that you have got these things from Jonathan?

SP.SPEAKER: Crib,
SP.P: (with hesitation.) Yes, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: You have cheated him, but that is no matter. Jonathan lost them, and has merited his fortune. We will put a value on them.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: I could wish, indeed, that I had sufficient to redeem my loss.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: O sir, if all that I have in my pocket be suf∣ficient, Jonathan may command it. I have full five gui∣neas, take them for the service of my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: Augustine, this is very generous.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: What, to me such friendship!

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: We are neighbours both, and you may pay me weekly, or in any way you please. (Crib gives Jona∣than his things.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher,
SP.P: (to Jonathan.) Is every thing returned you?

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: Yes, sir; and I am saved by your generosity and Augustine's from the resentment of my father. Oh, I will never risque his gifts again in such a manner.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher,
SP.P: (offering Crib the money.) Here is the value of your theft, for such it must be called; and you shall have it to subsist upon in prison till you are called to aner for your crime, as possibly you may not have the means without it. Nay, expect not by solicitation to divert the rigour of my justice. Your seduction of two youths, your felony upon the property of this young man, and your attempt to make him instrumental in the rob∣bery of another, well deserve that rigour. This must be your sentence; so withdraw a little for the present. (Crib withdraws, and weeps for very rage)

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan,
SP.P: (falling on his knees to Mr. Fletcher.) O dear Sir! from what a gulph of ruin you preserve me! And without you what would have been my evil fortune, when thrust out from home, and perhaps stigmatized in public for my vices? I am then indebted to your pity for my re∣putation, my repose, and my existence. (He rises and embraces Augustine.) And my generous Augustine, you whom I was going to—

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Never think more of it; I do not; and for the time to come be happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: Master Albert's testimony of your grief at being forced into this plot, alleviates your offence; and therefore you may still continue to visit my son; but after what he has just done in your behalf, I shall account you the most profligate of youths, unless you study to de∣serve his friendship.

SP.SPEAKER: Jonathan.
SP.P: Oh, I will do so. Rely upon me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: And as for you, dear Albert, I have rea∣son to be charmed with what so many tongues have told me of your modesty and virtue. By your laudable ex∣ample, you may very much contribute to the happiness of Augustine.—I request you to be often with him; and if I can shew my gratitude by being serviceable to your hap∣piness, I shall promote it with as much affection as your parents would do.

SP.SPEAKER: Albert.
SP.P: Your esteem, dear sir, is happiness sufficient for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: You observe, my dear children, the un∣happy consequences that result from gaming?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Yes, sir, and shall shudder all my life at the idea of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Fletcher.
SP.P: You observe too, Augustine, with what care and circumspection one should chuse a friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustine.
SP.P: Yes, that too, sir; and am convinced how happy it is for me to have a friend, as I have said already, in my father.

DIV2.HEAD: THE MONKEY.
DIV2.P: FRANCIS, and his play-mate Lorenzo, were at the window. As it chanced, they heard a pipe and ta∣bor. Looking up the street, they saw a bear approaching sternly, and a man conducting him by a chain to which the creature was fastened at the other end. I should be afraid, said Lozenzo, to stand too near that animal; for do but listen, Francis: Did you ever hear such growling? I should quake if I were by him. Oh, he could not hurt you, answered Francis; you may see, he has a muzzle to prevent his biting.

They were talking thus, when Bruin was come exactly opposite their window, in his progress down the street. Two monkies now took up the little gentlemen's atten∣tion. One was light and nimble, but the other not so active. Both were jumping to and fro on Bruin's back, who suffered them to play their tricks as if he did not care about it. They had fruit in plenty thrown them by the mob, which they caught in their paws as soon as it was flung to them, and swallowed almost instantly. But what delighted them particularly, were the nuts which the peo∣ple threw them. Seated on their breech, and holding them between their two fore-paws, they broke the shells, and picked the kernels out with something of an air.

It chanced that a very large one came among the rest. The heavy monkey raised himself upon his long hind-legs to get it; but the little one darting forward, seized it in the air before it could have time to reach him. Cheated of his prey in this manner by the little one, he gnashed his teeth with rage. His front grew wrinkled, and his eyes flashed fire: he thrust his claws out, fell upon the little one, and seemed upon the point of tearing him to bits. The bear found it very difficult to save him.

Do you see, said Francis to his little friend, how fright∣ful that same monkey is become since first he fell into a rage, and how he shews his teeth? Oh no, I should not like to be within his reach! How terrible! I should be scared to death!

Indeed? said Lorenzo. Well then, can you imagine it; but yesterday, when you were in a passion, you were like
him. Look ye, you had all his wrinkles; you even grinned as he does now; your eyes shewed what a passion you were in, and like the monkey, you seemed ready to devour poor little Harry, who had notwithstanding done you no great harm. I only wished that I could have got a looking-glass. Your face was in reality so ugly, it would have frightened you.

Indeed! said Francis. Is it possible that I resembled such an odious beast? I could not but have been extremely frightful if I did, and must endeavour for the future to be never in a passion. When I find myself growing angry, I will then bethink me of the monkey, recollect the ma∣lice in his countenance, and that will make me shudder at the thought of being like him. Do you too, my good friend Lorenzo, if I forget this resolution, like a friend remind me of it.

Lorenzo assured him that he would do so, and was faithful to his promise. Francis by degrees got rid en∣tirely of his wrathful habit, or was very rarely in a pas∣sion. He enjoyed the greater happiness, and his indulgent parents were not less transported at his reformation.

DIV2.HEAD: THE ALPS.
DIV2.P: THE sun was rising in the heavens. The dew drops which are seen on every leaf so early in the morning, glittered with the colours of the rainbow; and the shadows of the trees were shortening on the ground, when Damon, holding his son, a grown-up lad, by the hand, came out, and sat down on his garden terrace, to enjoy the freshness of the morning.

Dearest father, said the son, pray wake me always at this hour; for I am charmed with contemplating such a scene as I now see all round me! How delightful the whole prospect! But perhaps it would be more so, were it not confined by younder mountains, which lift up their snowy tops so high that any one would suppose them to prop the clouds above them.

I do not think as you do, said the father. Those same mountains leave us space enough, and that made up of
fields and meadows, to contemplate; and by thus consin∣ing, as you say, the prospect, help to vary it; and more particularly so at evening, when the sun still tips them with a thousand streaks of gold, even after the whole level plain is dark.
When we shall once have visited those mountains, and considered its inhabitants, you will be pleased with con∣templating on them, I am certain, since they cannot but suggest agreeable sensations.
How can men, said the youth, be fond of living on such mountains, covered as they are with snow?

They do not live there, said Damon; you will seek in vain to find inhabitants upon the heights: it is at the bot∣tom of the mountains that they are situated. There are charming vallies stretched among them; but before the traveller can obtain them, he discerns no prospect save that of barren rocks. This prospect being passed, he comes to wide extended carpets of the greenest sod; he breathes an air embalmed on all sides by ten thousand odoriferous flowers that grow there; and his ear is pleasingly affected by the murmurs of as many streams descending from the summit of the hills. The sun, by shining on them with his noon day radiance, makes them put on the appearance of the bightest silver. And amongst them, some, preci∣pitated from a rock, re-echo when they reach the bottom, and there rise in clouds, as one may say, of dust, that yield a trembling kind of light. Their passage is distin∣guished by a multitude of charming flowers which blossom on the margin; and the flowers, whose stalks wave to and fro, obedient to the breeze that agitates them, and the waters that flow in among them, heighten the delightful prospect.

Spring is very late, and harvest very early, in this re∣gion; whence it happens that the ground brings forth no other sort of grain than what is sowed some little while before the summer, and grows ripe betimes in autumn: hence, too, it comes that the fields are shaded by no other trees than those producing cherries, plums, and other early fruit. Here and there the traveller meets with amets; and the houses being made of wood, are so much blackened by the sun, as to afford a very striking contrast with the smiling verdure of the little orchards that surround them.

In those hamlets live many innocent and happy families, which for the space of five or six long months are almost buried under snow. As long as that sad season lasts, they take the greatest care imaginable of their little flocks; at times they visit one another, spin the flax which they have gathered before hand, and make different articles of furniture in wood, which they either use themselves, or are sure to fell for money to their neighbours.

As soon towards summer as the sun has melted that vast heap of snow which covered all their fields and habi∣tations, and the river that flows through their vallies has completely carried off the water with which their lands were overflowed, all the men begin to cultivate their fields or meadows, and the women labour in their gardens. During summer, the industrious father of his family re∣pairs to other districts with the produce of his labours, and brings back, in barter for them, those conveniencies of life which are not to be had for money even in his hamlet.

Many travel upon mules, and cross their craggy hills along such paths as have been cut through rocks, and those, too, over frightful precipices. They transport to very distant parts the honey which they have stored in autumn, which is universally acknowledged to be excel∣lent. They likewise traffic in the skins of goats, which they entrap while climbing up the rocks, or find among them dead. Another article of merchandize for which they are distinguished, is the dormouse. This animal, benumbed by the excessive cold, retains in holes and cavi∣ties, which she digs for herself to serve by way of habita∣tion, and in which she lies rolled up almost like a ball and on a bed of hay, that heat and life which, with returning spring, the sun expands; and a fourth great object of their commerce is the crystal, which they contrive to quarry in the gaps or chasms of their highest rocks. And many, on the other hand, are guides to foreigners who have the curiosity to travel over, and inspect their frozen moun∣tains.

I myself have been upon them, like many others, guided in my way by one of those good men.—I call them good, in opposition to the multitudes that live in towns and civilized society.—But yet they have lost a great deal of their natural simplicity by frequent converse with such
foreigners as have employed them for guides. I admired the people, and their way of living; therefore, having satisfied my curiosity upon the mountains, I determined to remain among them some few days, that I might gain a better knowledge of their manners.

I must let you know what conversation I heard pass be∣tween the wife and child of my conductor while I lived among them. I was sitting on the grass, beneath a pine∣tree: Julian, my conductor, had that day set out before the dawn, to guide two English gentlemen who came on the preceding evening to inspect the mountains. It was still broad day-light, but the sun was rapidly descending towards the west. The mother ascended upon a rising ground; the son came after her. They fixed their eyes upon the icy masses which advanced their cloggy cliffs on the other side of the valley, and the wife began as fol∣lows:

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother.
SP.P: I am looking to no purpose. I discover nothing. I do not see him yet.

SP.SPEAKER: The Son.
SP.P: Let us go to yonder rock before us, shaded by those trees, and we shall see much better thence. There we shall be able to discern more plainly all that quarter of the mountain where my father, I suppose, must be.

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother.
SP.P: Well, we are now got to it; notwithstand∣ing which, I can distinguish nothing more than from the spot that we have left. It is all lost labour: he does not appear. And yet the sun is nearly setting, and the day will soon close in.

SP.SPEAKER: The Son.
SP.P: O! mother, we shall yet have two full hours of day-light.

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother.
SP.P: And perhaps he may be four or five leagues distant. Who can tell exactly where he is? I wish he would give over wandering thus among the mountains. Never does he set out on his journies, but I tremble lest unfortunately he should not return alive: or else come back with broken limbs by falling down upon the ice, or while he scales the rocks.

SP.SPEAKER: The Son.
SP.P: I need not tell you that he has promised to drive this trade no longer, when the profits which he has made shall be enough to buy the little field between our cottage and the Arva.—We shall then live comfortably, with our flock, our honey, fruits, and field of barley.

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother.
SP.P: Ah! dear son, I should much rather wish to live in less abundance, so that I might only have more peace of mind. The happy days which we are to have when he has obtained this field, will have been bought too dearly, at the price of that distress and trouble which these his journies cost. But do not I see him? No, not yet. If he should be obliged to stay all night upon the ice!— If it—but you have got, I see, that spying-glass which a traveller lately left behind him in our hut, and that brings objects fifty furlongs off as near as if they were but ten. Look therefore if there is nothing to be seen. You know the use of it extremely well; but I, for my part, not at all.

SP.SPEAKER: The Son.
SP.P: I will rest the end of it on this old trunk. I think, I see—yes, mother—something, and it moves.— It is he, I verily believe!—Yes, yes, it is he indeed!— He is walking on the broken flakes of ice that lie near yon big rock, and which last month, you know, were separated from it.

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother.
SP.P: Let me have the spying-glass. Quick! quick! perhaps, too, I may see him.—I must shut one eye, you say?—I have;—but I distinguish nothing. Every thing is black.—Stay, stay. O now I see the rock!—and likewise men! and Julian is among them! But I have lost them now: they are out of sight: I cannot recover them again. Hold you the glass; I shall perhaps discern them with my naked eye.—Yes, yes, I see them. They are coming on, and in the middle of the valley. Julian, I can see, comes first.

SP.SPEAKER: The Son.
SP.P: They stop: my father sticks his pole into the ice before him, and prepares to take a spring. There, there! he is up, and down again. No doubt but there was one of those large gaps before him in the ice, of which he has so often told us. What can cause them?

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother.
SP.P:
I do not know exactly; but have heard that when the ice below is melted, that above it, having no support, gives way, and opens with a noise which one may hear a great way off. You have observed the great round table in our curate's kitchen? Well, the leg which supported it in the middle was much higher than the others, and one day the sides had many heavy things laid on them. Unexpectedly it split exactly in the middle, and the crack grew wider, till the sides could rest upon
the shorter legs. And now I suppose these gaps are so occa∣sioned likewise. But look once again, and see what they are doing. They seem standing still. The gap sure does not prevent them from advancing?

SP.SPEAKER: The Son.
SP.P: I can see their countenances very plainly. They seem asking one another what they ought to do. Ah! now my father takes a second spring; and now he is got safe over one more gap.

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother.
SP.P: Yes, yes; I see him too. What rashness! He might slip in springing, or when over; or he might not possibly spring far enough, and drop into the gap. He does not take a single step but what he knows, as well as I do, makes my heart sink within me. He should think that it is not impossible but I may see him; he should argue within himself, and say, My wife does see me, and my danger frights her.

SP.SPEAKER: The Son.
SP.P: He is very far, perhaps, from guessing what we are about now.

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother.
SP.P: He knows that, while he is absent on this dangerous business, I send forth my eyes to seek him. Would to heaven I could but shut them.

SP.SPEAKER: The Son.
SP.P: Yes, let us do so, mother. Let us put our hands before them, and not look again till he has cleared the valley, and is safe.

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother.
SP.P: I cannot. I had rather tremble every mo∣ment for his safety, than lose sight of him, though for a moment only. But where is he? I can see him now no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: The Son.
SP.P: Nor I either.—They have disappeared. Ah, mother!

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother.
SP.P:
My poor child! embrace me. We are now left to ourselves, and I have nothing in the world to com∣fort me but you. Yes, they have disappeared indeed; and in a moment too! I did but turn away my eyes to fix them upon you, and in that instant they are vanished! An abyss perhaps has opened under them as they were going on: perhaps they may be tossing in it, not yet dead, but making unavailing efforts to get out, and calling for assistance with a voice which no one, to their cost, is nigh enough to hear. I will hasten to the spot: come, follow me, my child! My knees knock one against another, and will hardly bear my body up; but I shall soon find strength sufficient to go forward. Come; but stay a little!
—Do not you, dear child, see something there in mo∣tion? There, just where I point to; at the bottom of you rock?

SP.SPEAKER: The Son.
SP.P: Yes, yes; I think I do.—It is one of them. —It is one of them, indeed; and now I can discern the other. I can see his hat; but still I look in vain to find out my poor father.

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother.
SP.P: He will come, and I dare hope to see him very soon. The gentlemen must first have got out of the frozen valley, and they hide him from us. Doubtless it will not be long before we see him. Look again, my child.

SP.SPEAKER: The Son.
SP.P: I can see only the two gentlemen; my father is not with them.

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother.
SP.P: And the gentlemen, do they seem waiting for him then? Have they their faces turned towards the place from which they come?

SP.SPEAKER: The Son.
SP.P: No; they walk strait forward.

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother.
SP.P: Then so much the better. If your father were not following them, or could not, they would hardly do so: they would try whatever they were able to assist him in his danger.

SP.SPEAKER: The Son.
SP.P: Yes, yes; we should do as much; but they, on the other hand, seem rich; and I have often heard that such despise the poor.

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother.
SP.P: Not all; and then, too, they are men, and must be sensible of people's misery like others. Would not you stretch forth a hand to help your little dog, were he in danger? Would you leave him unassisited?

SP.SPEAKER: The Son.
SP.P: No indeed: but why? because I love him: and do rich men love the poor? I have had money given me by one rich man to fight my play-mate.—Ah! I think I see my father now; yes, there he is! yes, yes, indeed; and, as you said, behind the gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother.
SP.P: Yes, yes; I see him too. Thank God! But still my heart beats grievously. I am in a tremble: So let us both sit down; we will have our eyes fixed on them till they are safe on this side of the valley; and by that time, as I hope, my agitation will be calmed. Me∣thinks they come on very quick. No doubt they wish to end their journey before day shuts in. Look, son: I fancy they are drawing nigh a precipice before them; and my fears again came on me.

SP.SPEAKER: The Son.
SP.P: It is a mass of ice that forms a hollow under∣neath. It looks as if it were suspended in the air, and they do not seem to know their danger; for they stop.

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother.
SP.P: They stop! and may, perhaps, without expecting it, be swallowed up, or buried in the ruins, should the ice fall down! It will fall down, and I shall see—oh heavens! fly for your life, my Julian! my dear Julian! fly! see what a mass of ice may overwhelm you! Fly!—My voice, alas! at such a distance, is not to be heard. My cries are useless. I am distracted!

SP.SPEAKER: The Son.
SP.P: Mother, I can see no longer through the spying-glass, because I cry; and yet I cannot take away my eyes. But now I see again. Yes, there they are, and they have cleared the precipice, quite cleared it. They are out of danger now: I see them: they turn back to view the rock under which they have passed, perhaps, without knowing at the time what peril they encountered. They lift their arms up; they are talking to each other; they are looking at some object that astounds them.

SP.SPEAKER: The Mother.
SP.P: They are out of danger; that is enough for me. I see them: they have nothing now but level ground remaining. Kiss me, my dear child! and let us both pass on to meet your father. But at no time in my life shall I forget what I have felt this afternoon. Let us make all possible haste, and beg that he would no more thus venture into danger. We shall have the little field, in that case, somewhat later; or it may be not at all; and it is no matter. We have lived till now without it: our enjoyments have not been on that account the less; we have in short been happy, and what more can we desire? I shall not for the future know that he is returning to those frozen regions, without fearing every danger that I know, and such as I can but guess. He may, perhaps, be safe feated at his ease beneath a tree; but I shall fancy that I behold him struggling in a gap, and striving to get out. Whatever money he receives from those whom he may conduct,—if he but loves us, he should think that he buys it at a price too dear.

DIV2.P:
The mother and the son upon this went forward, and I followed them till they had gained the valley. They pressed on to meet a husband, and a father; and at last, when they observed him with the Englishmen draw near, they durst not note him. They sat down together, let
him pass, and then got up and followed slowly after. It was not before they reached their cottage, that the wife and son ran both to Julian, and together sunk into his arms. The son related every thing which they had both seen and feared. The mother did not speak at first; but when she saw her husband touched by the affectionate behaviour of his son, she once again embraced him and shed tears. He promised that he would never more af∣fright her by returning to the ice, but cultivate his field in peace.

DIV2.HEAD: THE BREAKFAST.
DIV2.P: COME, said Mr. Glassington to Percival his son, one beauteous summer morning, here is a basket with some cake and currants in it. Let us go and break∣fast by the river's side.

With all my heart, papa, said Percival, and jumped about for joy. He took the basket in one hand, and with the other in his father's, hastened towards the river. Having reached it, they walked on a little way to chuse a proper place; when Mr. Glassington arriving at a very pleasant spot, cried out, Let us stop here, Percival; for this methinks will yield us a delightful prospect, while we sit and eat.

SP.SPEAKER: Percival.
SP.P: But how are we to eat without a table?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Glassington.
SP.P: Fortunately, here is the trunk of an old tree, which would serve by way of table very well, if we had need of one; but you may eat your currants as they lie together in the basket.

SP.SPEAKER: Percival.
SP.P: So I can: but how shall we supply the want of chairs?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Glassington.
SP.P: And do you reckon this soft grass then nothing? See how thick it is set with flowers. We will take our seat upon it: or perhaps you would rather chuse the carpet?

SP.SPEAKER: Percival.
SP.P: Chuse the carpet! Why you know, papa, the carpet is fast nailed down upon the parlour floor.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Glassington.
SP.P: It is true, there is a carpet there; but there is one here also.

SP.SPEAKER: Percival.
SP.P: I do not see it, if there is.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Glassington.
SP.P: Why, what is the grass then, but a carpet for the fields? And what a charming one too! It is of a fresher colour, and much downier than any one that we have. Then how spacious! it covers every hill, and all the level plain. The lambs repose upon it at their ease. Think, Percival, what they would have to suffer, on a bare or stony piece of ground! Their limbs are so extremely delicate, they could not but be very quickly injured. They have mothers, but those mothers cannot make them up soft feather-beds. God therefore has pro∣vided for them better than the poor sheep can, and made them this soft couch, where they may roll about, or sleep entirely at their ease.

SP.SPEAKER: Percival.
SP.P: And then, papa, there is one good thing be∣fides, that they may eat it when they like.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Glassington.
SP.P: Oho! I understand your meaning: so here take your cake and currants.

SP.SPEAKER: Percival,
SP.P: (biting off a bit.) Oh! how good! There is nothing wanting but a story while I am eating. Will you tell me one, papa; the prettiest that you know?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Glassington.
SP.P: With all my heart. Your cake reminds me of a story that I can tell about three cakes.

SP.SPEAKER: Percival.
SP.P: One, two, three cakes! Oh, what a charm∣ing story that must be! So quick, papa, and tell it me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Glassington.
SP.P: Come then first, and sit beside me. Be wholly at your ease, and then you will hear the better.

SP.SPEAKER: Percival.
SP.P: I am quite ready; so begin, papa.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Glassington.
SP.P:
THERE was a little boy named Henry, about your age. His pa∣rents had but lately fixed him at a boarding-school. He was a special boy, for ever at his book, and happened once to get the highest place at exercises. His mama was told it. She could no how keep from dreaming of the pleasure; and when morning came, she got up early, sent to speak with the cook, and said as follows: Cook, you are to make a cake for Henry, who yesterday was very
good at school. With all my heart, replied the cook, and set immediately about it. It was as big as—let me see,—as big as—as a hat when flapped. The cook had stuffed it with nice almonds, large Pistachio nuts, and candied lemon-peel, and iced it over with a coat of sugar, so that it was very smooth, and of a perfect white. The cake no sooner was come home from baking, than the cook put on her things, and carried it to school. When Henry first saw it, he jumped up and down like any Merry An∣drew. He was not so patient as to wait 'till they could let him have a knife, but fell upon it tooth and nail.— He ate and ate 'till school began, and after school was over he ate again: at night too it was the same thing 'till bed-time.
