Pascal, whose intemperance had hurt his inside much, endured a great deal more than any other. He was several days insensible, and nothing staid upon his stomach. Even the sight of food disgusted him; and when at last he grew a little better, and was hungry, mouldy pease, salt beef, and biscuits full of mag∣gots, were the only victuals that he could procure. When he first set sail, the soldiers had a pint of beer each allowed them; but by degrees they were deprived of this indul∣gence, and compelled to put up with a bare sufficiency of water, and even this they were obliged to strain before they could drink it.

After six long months incessant suffering, during all which time they were in fear of continual shipwreck, they arrived in India, wearied out with watchings for the most part, and a dreadful scurvy. Pascal was marched up the country, with his comrades, to the army: but his heart, embittered by the horror of his situation, was insensible of any thing like goodness. His abandoned course of life, the crimes that he was incessantly committing, and his numberless desertions, frequently subjected him to pu∣nishment. He was determined, if he could, to quit these regions, watched his opportunity, and stealing on board a vessel bound to England, hid himself below till it had sailed; nor did he quit his hiding place, till the ship was a great way out to sea: he then came sorth, and being brought before the captain, promised to work his passage to England; which the captain in the end accepted, as the vessel was in want of men.

What, in the interim, was become of his unhappy pa∣rents? They alas! still lived, if people may be said to live whose sad days are spent in anguish and despair. The crimes which their son had committed, and with which the neighbourhood all around them rung, had forced them to renounce their place of habitation, and go down and live in Sussex, in a solitary quarter near the sea.

A short time after they were settled here, the ship, in which Pascal was, arrived on that very part of the coast where they had fixed their retirement. For while they were a little way out to sea, Pascal, a thorough graduate in vice, had conspired with ten or twelve desperate fellows
of the crew, to murder every one on board who would not join in their conspiracy, and so obtain possession of the ship. They executed their infernal purpose; and soon after running the vessel ashore, they hoisted out their boat at night, that they might come on shore, and pillage the inhabitants.

That very night the unhappy Mr. Dawkins in his house was up, and watching by his wife's sick bed. Her grief for Pascal's wretched fortune had long preyed upon her constitution; and by this time, after having suffered grievously, she felt the agonies of death upon her. In the intervals of her delirium, she called out for Pascal: Where, where are you, said the dying mother? Come, that I may press you to my heart, and pardon you before I die. At this the door is suddenly burst open, and ten villains rush into the dwelling. Pascal, with a hatchet in his hand, was first, and led them on. The father comes to meet them with a candle; but before his son could recollect him—The remainder is too horrid to relate: suffice it, that Pascal and his gang were apprehended on the spot, and suffered at the gallows.

Children, if when you have read this story, you dare think of giving way to any vice whatsoever, tremble at the possibility of your becoming criminal by degrees, and ending like Pascal with the crime of parricide!

DIV3.HEAD: CHARACTERS.
DIV3.P: The SCENE is in the country, at the Countess's, and in two rooms which open to the garden.

SP.STAGE: Jenny, (reckening up the counters on a table.)
SP.P: IT is all lost labour to stand counting thus. I cannot make more than ninety-four; and yet there should be an hundred. Well, I think, there never was a house like ours for hare-brained children; for wherever they once put their foot, one may be sure, they will jumble every thing together, if they do not lose something or another. I must look about for them in every corner of the chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: You seem uneasy, Jenny: What are you seeking?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Your ladyship's best counters.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Do not you see them on the table?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Yes, my lady; but the number is not complete.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: That should not be.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: That should not be, indeed; and yet there are no less than half a dozen wanting. Were there not an hundred?

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Yes; you know it as well as I.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Well then, there are but ninety-four.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess,
SP.P: (after having counted them.) There are indeed no more; and yet last night the number was complete. I put them up myself, when we had finished playing. But what caused you to come now, and count them up?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Because, as I passed by the door, I saw that the children had been playing with them.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Yet I absolutely ordered that they should not be touched. They have ivory ones to play with: who could give them these?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Themselves.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Themselves! Where are they?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: In the garden, madam, with their little com∣pany.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Fetch Julia here.—But stay, have none been here but Julia and Augustus?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Yes, their friends: and who can tell—

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: What, Jenny! can you possibly suspect—

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: I will answer for your children, please your ladyship, and likewise the three young Davenports, as if they were myself.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: And not the others?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: I do not know them well enough.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: What, Jenny, two such children as the Hon. Mr. Oddly and his sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: If your ladyship thinks sit, I'll call Miss Julia in: but here she comes.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess,
SP.P: (to Julia coming in.) Who told you, miss, to use my silver counters? Did not I forbid you to meddle with them?

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: It was not my fault, mama.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: And whose then, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P:
The Hon. Mr. Oddly's and his sister's. I had got the ivory counters, when they asked me if I meant to
play with them, as they never had such at home, and must have better; upon which they opened all the drawers and closets till they met with these.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Why did not you mention that I would never let you use them?

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: Good! as if they would hear me! I believe they would have beat us, had we not surrendered them.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Upon my word! These children, as it seems, are charmingly brought up!

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: You should at least have counted them when you left off playing.

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: That was what I wished to do. But after I had got to twenty-four or thereabouts, Mr. Oddly snatched them from me, put them up pell-mell, and dragged us out into the garden with him.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Do you know that six are missing?

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: Sure, mama!

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: How! sure! when I have told you! See now whether one can trust you in the least! You know, it was your duty to take care of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: I was confounded, dear mama; these children are so mischievous! I was obliged to have my eye conti∣nually on them, as I thought they would have broke your china. I was obliged frequently to follow them about the room: they may have flung the counters, then, into some corner or another.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Well, but I must have them found.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: I know but one way, madam. Were I you, I would turn the little master's pockets inside out before they left the house.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Fie, Jenny! would you have me affront their parents?

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: Oh! I am sure, mama, not one among them can have stolen the counters,

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: So I think; but children of their age may be a little giddy-headed. So go to them, Julia, and politely ask if any one among them may not by mistake have put them up into his pocket. Your commission is a nice one, and requires a little management. Take care not to offend them, by insinuating that you think any one of the company capable of taking them purposely.

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: I shall take care, mama.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Accuse yourself of negligence, and tell them that I shall blame you, if they are not soon found.

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: I understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: And bid Robert, as you pass, come here.

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: I will, mama.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny,
SP.P: (who has been employed in looking round the room.) I will answer for it, they are not here: there is not a cor∣ner but I have searched.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: This should not have happened in my house. I dread, yet long to know, by what means they are vanished.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Here I am, my lady: what is your pleasure?

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: To inform you, Robert, that I have lost since yesterday six counters.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Does your ladyship suspect me of taking them?

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: God forbid! I am too well acquainted with your honesty for that. But I suppose, if you had crossed the room, you might have seen them on some chair or elsewhere.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Counters on a chair?

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: I know, that is not a proper place for counters; but the children have been playing where they were, and might have inconsiderately left them in some corner, and you seen them.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: No, my lady, I have not.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: I am sorry for it, and do not know what method to pursue. They must have certainly been lost since morning, as I counted them myself last night.—But look about.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Your ladyship has seen how I have been search∣ing for them. Servants are but badly off, when any thing is lost about a house. However honest they may be, they are constantly suspected.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Very likely; but the honest servant will on this occasion pardon me, if I include her in my search of the dishonest.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: You may first of all examine me, my lady. Rogues are constantly the first to be displeased when they are suspected.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: God be thanked, I have no fear of that sort! But it cannot be a matter of indifference to the honest servant, when a thief is in the house.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: But put yourself into my place; what would you do? Think, Robert.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Do, my lady?—A thought this moment strikes me; and provided I have leave to put it into execution, I will engage to find the counters.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: But you must not think of giving any one occasion to suppose himself suspected.—What is your design?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: I cannot at present tell your ladyship. A single syllable might spoil the business. Do but bring together all the children in the adjoining room. I promise you, the thief, if there is any thief among them, shall betray himself.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: I cannot tell whether I should let—

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: You can trust me, madam. Be assured that no one but the guilty person shall have reason to complain; and him, I dre believe, you would not wish to spare.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Well, Robert, as I know your prudence, I rely upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Good! my lady. Therefore I will go and begin conjuring. Do not be afraid! it is quite simple.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: My lady—did not he say something about con∣juring? But that I know myself innocent, I should be frightened out of my wits.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Peace, simpleton!

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: What now, Augustus? You seem big with something or another! Have you brought the counters with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustus.
SP.P: No, mama: I have only learned that six are lost. My sister told us so just this moment.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: And how was the intelligence received?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustus.
SP.P: We were exceedingly surprized. The two Davenports particularly, and their sister, want to come and plead their innocence before you.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Plead! they are the last that I should suspect of such a deed. And the Hon. Mr. Oddly—

SP.SPEAKER: Augustus.
SP.P: Oh! he is furious; and told Julia, that to look upon him as a thief, was but a bad reception.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Julia was not rude, I hope, in telling them my message.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustus.
SP.P: No, mama, quite otherwise. She spoke with great politeness.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Then pray why was Mr. Oddly angry? There was nothing personal in what your sister said.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustus.
SP.P: I cannot well tell the reason; but Eliza drew him privately aside: he would not condescend to hear her. He is determined to be gone: his hat is fortunately here; he will come and fetch it, and declares that he will not remain a minute in the house. He threatens to complain to his papa.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Positively he must not go. I will tell his lordship the whole affair myself, when he comes to take him home.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustus.
SP.P: The rest wish greatly for permission to appear and justify themselves before you.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: There is no need of that. I only wished to know if they could give me any information of the counters. They are all of them too well brought up, that I should venture to accuse them of a theft. ut I am well acquainted with the whims of children. They will see every thing, and finger every thing; and from a want of thought, might easily have put a thing into their pocket, without any criminal intention.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustus.
SP.P: Certainly they might, mama; as I did, you remember, when I took my sister's purse up by mistake, and would have carried it away.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: But softly! here they are.—Go, Jenny, and enquire if Robert is preparing matters. (Jenny goes out.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VIII.
DIV3.STAGE: The Countess, Augustus, Julia, the Hon. Mr. Oddly, Eliza, Gabriel, Lucius, Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Well, how fares it with you all, my little friends? I am glad to see you here.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: Miss Julia has just now informed us, that your ladyship has lost six counters of the number with which unluckily we were playing. I am sorry for it; but could never think that your ladyship would have sus∣pected any one of us of having taken them. At least I can assure you for my sister and myself, that we know no∣thing of them.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: God forbid that I should suspect such well∣bred children, as I look upon you all to be. Sure Julia did not tell you that I supposed you to have the counters?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: No, my lady; all that she said, was to enquire if we had brought them out through inattention, or to play a little longer with them in the garden.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Which you might very innocently have done. It is she alone that I blame in the affair, because she did not let you have her counters.

SP.SPEAKER: Gabriel.
SP.P: She designed, I think, to use them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucius.
SP.P: I would never dare to shew my face again, if I had taken so much as a pin.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia,
SP.P: (emptying her pockets.) See, my lady, I have nothing here: and there are no other pockets to my slip.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: My dear children, I have already told you that I am far from suspecting any of you to have them, when you say that you have not. They are certainly of no great value; yet I cannot but confess, that their loss affects me.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P:
Were they only worth a straw, they are your ladyship's, and should not now be missing. But you know, there are such things as servants; and they
are not always very honest. It is not the first time that we have suspected them at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: But it is the first time that any thing of the kind has happened in our house, dear Mr. Oddly, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustus.
SP.P: I would answer for our servants, men and women.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: I have trusted them this long time; but if you, sir, (to the Hon. Mr. Oddly,) have made any observa∣tions, I request you to let me know them.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: O, no no!—But when we went into the garden, did not—what is her name—the house∣maid enter?

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Jenny! Oh! I do not fear her. These six years past that I have had her, she might easily have made away with things of value, had she been dishonest.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: Did not your old footman come in likewise? I do not like his looks; and should not chuse to meet him in a lane at night.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Fie, sir! what makes you thus suspect the honest Robert? He was my father-in-law's confidential servant, and has been much longer in the family than even I myself. If he could possibly turn pilferer, neither you nor I could know what living creature we might trust.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: It is not unlikely then, but some one may have got into the room when we were gone.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: That is not at all unlikely; and I am go∣ing to enquire. Amuse yourselves till I come back.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: No, madam; after what has passed, I cannot stay longer here. Augustus, can you tell me where they have put my hat?

SP.SPEAKER: Augustus.
SP.P: It is taken to be brushed; you will have it brought you.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: I must have it instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: But won't you stay a little for papa? You know, he means to come and fetch us.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: I cannot possibly let you go home on foot. You would have upwards of three miles to walk. Stay here till I return: I will not detain you long.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IX.
DIV3.STAGE: Augustus, Julia, the Hon. Mr. Oddly, Eliza, Gabriel, Lucius, Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: I am very much astonished that your mama should have such thoughts of us! We steal her counters!

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: Sir, she never had such a thought. She might have fancied that we had put them, without thought, into our pockets. I might as easily have taken them in this way, as yourself, or any other: but to steal! she did not men∣tion the word, or any like it.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: Had there been none here but tradesmen's children, she might well have entertained suspicions: but she should make some difference now.

SP.SPEAKER: Gabriel.
SP.P: You speak of us, sir, I can see: your looks inform me so. But let me tell you, in my turn, that it is one's manners and principles, and not birth, that makes one truly noble.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: How these tradesmen talk about their manners! You are very happy that there are so few children hereabout, and that Augustus and myself are forced to make you our companions, or have no diversion. Did you live in London, you would not have such an honour, notwithstanding your fine manners.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustus.
SP.P: Speak, sir, for yourself alone; for just as here, in London too, I should be proud to entertain my little friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: Yes, certainly. They give us, to the full, as good examples as such whipper-shapper noblemen as you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: This, brother, you have deserved. Why attack them first?

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: And you, too, upon me? You think certainly as I do, though you will not confess it. Have you forgot mama's instruction on the subject of fa∣miliarity with those beneath us? "Never mix with tradesmen's children: in the lower ranks of life, you will always have low thoughts."

SP.SPEAKER: Augustus.
SP.P: And can you possibly suspect that my friends are capable of being thieves?

SP.SPEAKER: Gabriel.
SP.P: Did we approach the table?

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: No: whereas we saw you take the counters, and look at them I suppose half a dozen times. (The Hon. Mr. Oddly attempts to strike her. Augustus and Gabriel hold his hand.)

SP.SPEAKER: Augustus.
SP.P: Softly! You will have to deal with me else.

SP.SPEAKER: Gabriel.
SP.P: No, no, my friend. I thank you, but I can take care of my sister. Let him even threaten her. I am not a bit more frightened at his size than his title.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: Oh! it is far beneath me to dis∣pute with traders.

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: Very well: I hope then it is beneath you like∣wise to attack a little girl.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: I shall not permit her to insult me.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: She would certainly have done much better, had she held her tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: But being such a child, she might be pardoned: and particularly when she spoke the truth.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: The truth? What do mean by that?

SP.SPEAKER: Gabriel.
SP.P: She said, that you took the counters and looked at them: that is all. Did she say any more? And this certainly was true.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: I shan't even condescend to answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Gabriel.
SP.P: You cannot take a better resolution, when you have nothing but such answers for us.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE X.
DIV3.STAGE: Augustus, Julia, the Hon. Mr. Oddly, Eliza, Gabriel, Lucius, Sophia, the Countess.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: What is the meaning of all this? I will not have any quarrels here!

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: My lady, I expect, you will do me justice on these little folks!

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Folks! folks! who are they? I am not accustomed to have such as visit here called so.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustus.
SP.P: He is angry, since we were not in a humour to endure his airs.

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: He thought he should have had a company of dukes at least for play-fellows.

SP.SPEAKER: Gabriel.
SP.P: And imagines that we should be suspected of this theft, much rather than a nobleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucius.
SP.P: As if we had not a character to keep, as well as he has!

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Ay, and would have beat me, had not Gabriel taught him better.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Why, sure! it is not possible!

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: To say the truth, my brother is too hasty.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Vivacity becomes his age very well; but we should not be proud, quarrelsome, or rash. Oh! here is Robert.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XI.
DIV3.STAGE: The Countess, Augustus, Julia, the Hon. Mr. Oddly, Eliza, Gabriel, Lucius, Sophia, Robert (carrying a basket covered with a napkin.)

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: There is no more to be said, my lady. Every body in this house is innocent, as sure as my name is Robert; but however, for the satisfaction of the company, I will introduce my cock, who, you must know before∣hand, is a conjurer. (Putting down the basket on the table.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia,
SP.P: (jumping for joy.) O, a cock! a cock!

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Yes, nothing more; for look you! (He lifts up a napkin in the basket, so that Sophia and the rest discern the creature's neck and crest.) Just like others, saving that my cock has not his equal in the world for knowledge: why, he will tell me things which no other person possibly can know. If a single straw, and nothing else, is missing, I need only run and have a consultation with him: he will be sure to know who stole it.

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: You can then find out our counters, can you?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Can I? Why last Christmas, at the alehouse, I had lost my pipe; so what did I do, but away and fetched my cock, who let me know that the groom had got it: and I think, you recollect, he broke his leg about a fort∣night after.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: He can talk then?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Yes, like other cocks: Cock, cock-a-doodle-doo. On which, I understand him just as if it were you that spoke to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: Yet you never told us this before.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Because we never yet lost any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Well, now, a truce to all this conversa∣tion, and begin.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Not quite so fast, my lady. I must perform my conjuring in the dark.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: A very easy matter. You need only close the shutters.

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: I will go out and push them to.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: You are much too short: you cannot reach them. Robert will do that himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Yes, madam. (He goes out.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XII.
DIV3.STAGE: The Countess, Augustus, Julia, the Hon. Mr. Oddly, Eliza, Gabriel, Lucius, Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustus,
SP.P: (with the rest, excepting the Hon. Mr. Oddly, who appears embarrassed, lifting up the napkin.) This same cock seems supernatural, I fancy. (Looking at him earnestly.) How his eyes shine!

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: And his comb, how red it looks! my patience! how it shakes upon his head!

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Do you imagine, then, that it has so much knowledge as Robert says?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucius.
SP.P: Papa has often told us, what we ought to think of such strange stories.

SP.SPEAKER: Gabriel.
SP.P: Robert is a cunning sportsman, and I am sure can make birds hold their tongue, much better with his fowling piece, than teach a cock to talk by virtue of his wand.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Who knows! my governess has told me many wond'rous things of conjuration, and all that.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: I wonder, sister, you can listen to such stories!

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: I am glad you have these notions of the matter, and should like to laugh at Robert for his folly. What simplicity! a cock discover thieves!

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly,
SP.P: (forcing a smile.) I fancy we shall have a deal of laughing very shortly. (The shutters are closed all at once.) But why put the shutters to? (with un∣easiness) I do not love darkness.

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: If the cock cannot see, he will never find the thief out.—Will he, pray, mama?

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Well asked: for I cannot tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: I should like, if I knew how, to make him speak. Come pretty little cock, say something.—See how dark it is.—Look out a little.—He does not speak a word!

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: The reason is, I suppose, he will obey his mas∣ter only. (Robert comes in again.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XIII.
DIV3.STAGE: The Countess, Augustus, Julia, the Hon. Mr. Oddly, Eliza, Gabriel, Lucius, Sophia, Robert.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Well, you are satisfied now, Robert, since you have thus shut out the day-light?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Yes, my lady; every thing is as it should be. And so now, let those remain that have not stolen the coun∣ters, but if any one is guilty, let that one go out.—What all remain!

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: How cunning!

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: I see clearly then that I must employ my art. (He waves his wand, and draws a circle on the floor; pro∣nouncing something unintelligible.)

Q.L: That's well! So now, my cock, take heed;
And tell us, who are rogues indeed.

SP.P: Come now my little gentlemen and ladies, and let every one of you in turn, lift up the napkin here, and with his right hand, do you see, stroke Chanticleer upon the back. You will hear his music, when the thief once puts his hand upon him: but do not lift the cloth too high; just high enough to let your hand pass under it.

Q.L: So now, my pretty cock, take heed;
And tell us who are rogues indeed.

SP.P: Well! what will none of you begin?

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: What, every one afraid? Why, one would think you all guilty, at this rate!

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: I am the youngest, but I will set the example. (She lifts up the cloth, and strokes the cock twice over in the basket.) Do you see, the cock does not speak. It is not I that have stolen the counters.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Very well. Stand now in this place, with your hand behind you.—Is it so?

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Feel, feel.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: That is right. Now you, sir. (To Augustus.)

SP.SPEAKER: Augustus.
SP.P: Oh! I fear as little as Miss Sophia.—There. —He has not spoke.—Must I too hold my hand behind me?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Certainly; and every one.—Come here, by this young lady.—Well, another.

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: I will go next.— (She strokes him.) If he had said a word, he would have been a story-teller.—

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: By your brother here. Who is next?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: It is my turn now. (She strokes him.) As mute as any mackerel.—Yet I stroked him four times over.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Are your right hands all behind you? Do not forget that part.

SP.SPEAKER: Gabriel,
SP.P: (to the Hon. Mr. Oddly.) I will follow you.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: As if I would have to do with such child's play!

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: You would not surely spoil our sport. A little complaisance, pray, Mr. Oddly.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: If that is all, I have no objection. — (He puts his hand under the cloth.) There.—I do not find he has spoke for me, though I have stroked him more than others.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Here, sir, with the rest; and keep your hand behind you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: There are none now, but my brothers left, that have not stroked him. It is one of them!—Oh, no; I do not think so. (Gabriel and Lucius imitate the others; upon which, the children all burst out a laughing.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lucius.
SP.P: And where is the thief?—Why no where.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Robert, you should send your cock to Norwood; he is not cunning enough: and all this while my counters are not found.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: I must acknowledge, this confounds me.—For a little while, however, patience; and do not stir.—Stand still, I say.—They are just like so much quick-silver!— My circle, as I think, must be imperfect. I will go fetch a candle, and examine. I pray your ladyship, let no one quit his place.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XIV.
DIV3.STAGE: The Countess, Augustus, Julia, the Hon. Mr. Oddly, Eliza, Gabriel, Lucius, Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: I knew before-hand, how all this would end.—Stupid nonsense!

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Why, this cock is no wiser than his master.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Truly, I am glad to see him caught.

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: And what does he design to do, when he has brought a light?

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: He will shew us.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: I should like to see the cock now.—He will scarce hold his head up, I suppose, for shame.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XV.
DIV3.STAGE: The Countess, Augustus, Julia, the Hon. Mr. Oddly, Eliza, Gabriel, Lucius, Sophia, Robert.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: (returning with a light, and going up to Sophia.) Come, let me see your little hand. (She holds him out the left.) Not this,—but that behind you. Good!

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia,
SP.P: (looking at her hand, and crying out.) Oh, what a hand I have! as black as any coal! And will it always be so?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Do not be frightened, little miss! I will speak about it to my cock, and you shall have both hands as white as snow.— (The children have not patience, but look all together at their hands, and instantly cry out at once.)

SP.SPEAKER: Augustus.
SP.P: How black my singers are too!

SP.SPEAKER: Julia.
SP.P: And mine likewise! What does Robert mean by this?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: I would twist the creature's neck off, if I had him.

SP.SPEAKER: Gabriel.
SP.P: Fegs! my wristbands are come in a little for it!

SP.SPEAKER: Lucius.
SP.P: It is as if my hand were painted!

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly,
SP.P: (lifting up his hand in triumph.) But see mine! There is none of the company that has a hand fit to look at, except me.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert,
SP.P: (taking hold of the Hon. Mr. Oddly by the collar.) Very likely! Then, sir, you have stole the counters.— Give them up, young gentleman, this instant, or I will search your pockets, and then blacken you all over!

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Blacken him? O, brother! if you have got the counters, give them up this moment.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Take care, Robert, what you say!

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: I am sure, he has them. So, quit the counters, or expect to have a countenance as grimy as the blackest negro's.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly,
SP.P: (turning pale and trembling.) Is it possible that I should have put them in my pocket, and not thought of what I was about? (He feels about him.) I recollect, indeed, I had them in my hand. (He seems sur∣prized at finding them thrust down into a corner of his waist∣coat pocket.) Dear me! they are here indeed! Who would have thought it? (All the children look at one another with surprise, while the Hon. Mr. Oddly stands confounded.)

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Robert! (he approaches) take away your cock and candle, and go open us the shutters. Take care (in a whisper) not to tell your fellow-servants how you found the counters. Say that they were thrust a great way back into the table-drawer.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: I will, my lady. (He goes out.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XVI.
DIV3.STAGE: The Countess, Augustus, Julia, the Hon. Mr. Oddly, Eliza, Gabricl, Lucius, Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess
SP.P: Go, my little friends, into the other room: you will find water there to wash your hands. Take care, and do not splash one another's clothes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: No, no:—but if this black should not come off?

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: It is nothing but a little ivory black, and water will remove it. You, sir, (to the Hon. Mr. Oddly,) as your hands are clean, may stay with me.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XVII.
DIV3.STAGE: The Countess, the Hon. Mr. Oddly.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Well then, my haughty little gentleman! and is it possible you could be guilty of so scandalous an action? You, that scarce a quarter of an hour ago looked down wih so much soorn upon the children of a reputable worthy tradesman, and supposed your quality disgraced by being in their company. They have at present their reverge, since they may call you, and with justice, a vile thief!

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: Pray pardon me, my lady!—I was playing with the counters—and without considering at the moment, must have put them into my pocket.—I have no other method of accounting for their being found upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Pitiful excuse! that aggravates your fault! At such a tender age as yours, could I have possibly ima∣gined one with so much front?

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: Believe me, madam, I had cer∣tainly no had design!—I took them without meaning so to do, and afterwards concealed the matter, from my crend of being taken for a thief.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: But after I had bid my daughter make enquiry for them with such delicacy, you might easily have seemed to search your peckets, and restored them without blushing. Your proceeding would have then been looked up was nothing but an inadvertoncy.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: I did not think of that, my lady.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: What then did you think, when you durst drop hints that possibly my honest servants might have taken them? or that my children's little friends were ob∣jects of suspicion? What were your ideas, when you made believe to stke the cock?

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: But, madam, I did stroke him.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P:
Hold your tongue, you little rascal!— for that is not too bad for your deservings. Hap∣plly, as yet, you have not got sufficient cunning to con∣ceal your wicked actions. You did stroke the cock! Is that then your assertion? Do not you see, that if you had, you would have blacked your hands as well as all the others,
Robert having smeared him over with a certain composi∣tion? Your companions were not in the least afraid to stroke him, as their conscience did not any way reproach them for the theft; but as for you, the apprehension lest the servant's artifice might really be conjuation awed you, and the means that you chose to avoid detection have be∣trayed you. Oh! how politic you thought yourself, I warrant, in pretending only, as you did, to stroke the cock; but honesty you would have found much better policy. You deserve that I should tell my lord, your father, of your laudable behaviour, when he comes to fetch you.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly,
SP.P: (falling on his knees.) Oh, no! Pray, my lady, I beseech you! He would beat me: he would tread me under foot.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: And it would be better that he should do so, than bring up a monster to disgrace him at some future period; for of what hereafter will you not be capable, since in the season of your infancy, as I may call it, you can perpetrate so great a crime?

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: Ah! madam, pardon me for pity's sake, and never—

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Doubtless you have often made these pro∣mises to others; for this hardly is your first transgression. Every circumstance confirms it. So much falsity and im∣pudence—

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: Then hear me, my good lady! If you ever heat, in future, that I make free with any thing whatsoever that is not mine—

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Inform me, in the first place, what did you intend to do with these six counters? You could hardly think that you would have any opportunity of using them, but they must instantly be known. You meant to sell them, then, for money?

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: No, believe me! I was pleased with looking at them. I supposed that no one would re∣member having seen them elsewhere, and on that account secreted them, my lady.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: And how could you desire to have ano∣ther's property? Confess! Is this your first offence?

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly,
SP.P:
(hiding his face.) No, no indeed, my lady. I have often been a thief at home; but never
having been suspected there, I hoped to have the same good fortune here.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: A very wicked sort of reasoning this! For, granting that no one upon earth suspected you, do not you know that God sees and punishes whatever people do amiss? Perhaps, however, this event is for your be∣nefit; and you will prove more likely to amend, when you have once been punished as you merit.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: Let it be by you, my lady, or by any one, but not by my papa. Let him know nothing of the matter, I conjure you. Tell it, if you please, to my mama, but keep the matter from his knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: There again! You would not have your father know it, as you fear the blows that he might be∣stow upon you. Thus, it is nothing but an abjectness that guides you, even in the work of your repentance; and it is not for his peace of mind that you would conceal it from him, for you are not afraid lest your mama should know it, because she would not beat you. It is not your idea to consult her peace of mind.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: Then tell it my preceptor.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: I am sensible, indeed, how much the knowledge of your fault would mortally afflict your pa∣rents, and from that consideration, not upon your own account, consent to spare you; but on this condition, that you come with your preceptor hither, and before him let me have your solemn promise of amendment. I will request him to keep watch upon your conduct; but if ever you should break your word, I will not only mention this adventure of the counters to his lordship, but let every body else know it.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: I consent you should do so, my lady.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: You might think that, after this, I should forbid your keeping company with Julia and Augustus; but I have at heart your reformation, and will judge thereof myself. You may continue therefore coming here.

SP.SPEAKER: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: But how shall I dare to face your servants?

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P:
You have nothing to fear upon that ac∣count, for I have had more care and forethought for your reputation than yourself, by telling Robert not to speak about it in the kitchen; and to hide your lie, have been
compelled to one myself, that they might not suppose you guilty.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: Ah! my lady, how much am I indebted to your bounty! I shall never forget the service that you have done me. But your children?—and the little com∣pany now with them?

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: I am well acquainted with their goodness, and am sure that they will forgive you. Call them. (Mr. Oddly, with a downcast look, goes slowly towards the door, and bids them enter.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XVIII.
DIV3.STAGE: The Countess, Mr. Oddly, Augustus, Julia, Eliza, Gabriel, Lucius, Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: Go, sir, you are a disgrace to me; I will never call you brother again.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: No, my dear Eliza, he is not so guilty as you think him. He has told me every thing. It was to play a little with the counters out of doors that he took them; but when once the matter seemed considered as a theft, he was terrified at the idea of incurring my suspi∣cion. This apparent guilt has sprung from a mistaken shame, which I am very willing to excuse; but not (look∣ing at the little Davenports) his scandalous endeavours to make you, my little dears, seem guilty.

SP.SPEAKER: Gabriel.
SP.P: Oh! my lady, we do not wish him any harm at present for it, as we know that we should forgive even such as wrong us, and particularly when we see them un∣happy.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: Do you mark that, Mr. Oddly? Such a conduct ought to shew you how much nobler it is to have an elevated way of thinking, than to boast an elevated birth. You find yourself entirely at the mercy even of those whom you have insulted; and, with all the boast of your nobility, you are the object of their pity.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: Oh, what shame! but I submit to undergo it.

SP.SPEAKER: Gabriel.
SP.P: We will never introduce again the mention of this matter. It shall be a secret for the time to come be∣tween us; shan't it, brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucius.
SP.P: Yes, he may rely upon my silence.

SP.SPEAKER: Gabriel.
SP.P: And you, sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: I will not have him beat. I know what pain it gives one, (Mr. Oddly in the transports of his gratitude em∣braces them.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: I desire, but dare not ask, to be acquainted with you for the future.

SP.SPEAKER: Gabriel.
SP.P: It will be doing us an honour, if you will still continue upon terms of friendship with us.

SP.SPEAKER: Augustus and Julia.
SP.P: And for our part, we shall be no less delighted with your company, as long as you regard our friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: You are all of you too good. He does not merit such indulgence, and papa must be informed of every thing.

SP.SPEAKER: The Countess.
SP.P: You will lose my friendship and esteem en∣tirely, I must tell you, Miss Eliza, could you possibly be unaffected with your brother's laudable repentance, when even strangers overlook his error. Do not employ the ad∣vantage that his offence affords you, to undo him in his parents' good opinion; but, for the future, let your coun∣sel shew him how to act, that he may merit their affection. I dare answer, you need never be ashamed of any action of his hereafter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Oddly.
SP.P: I should be unworthy of such bounty, if this lesson could be blotted out from my remembrance.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Take due care it be not, or Beware of the con∣juring Bird.
